questions.question: Which of the following statements about the pancreatic islets is correct?

options.A: A-cells are the most prevalent and primarily secrete insulin.
options.B: B cells constituting 60–75% of islet cells primarily secrete glucagon
options.C: F cells, which are the most abundant, primarily secrete pancreatic polypeptide.
options.D: B cells are the most prevalent and secrete insulin.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) B cells are the most prevalent and secrete insulin. Explanation: B cells are the most prevalent in the islets of Langerhans and they secrete insulin to lower blood glucose levels. Pancreas Overview: Location : Abdominal cavity Functions : Endocrine : Hormone secretion (Islets of Langerhans) Exocrine : Digestive enzyme secretion Islets of Langerhans : Size : 76–175 µm Distribution : Throughout the pancreas, concentrated in the tail Volume : ~2% of pancreas volume Blood Supply : Rich, drains into hepatic portal vein Islet Cell Types: Cell Type Percentage of Islet Cells Location Hormone Secreted Hormone Function B cells 60-75% Center Insulin (Option B) Lowers blood glucose A cell (Option A) 20% Surround B cells Glucagon Increases blood glucose D cells Less common Encircle B cells Somatostatin Regulates islet cell secretion F cells Less common (Option C) Encircle B cells Pancreatic polypeptide Regulates ion transport in the intestine Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 423, 424

questions.question: Which conditions would most likely result in a high insulin-glucagon molar (I/G ratio)?

options.D: Consumption of a large carbohydrate meal

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Consumption of a large carbohydrate meal Explanation: Eating a meal rich in carbohydrates significantly increases insulin secretion to promote the storage of glucose as glycogen, thus resulting in a high I/G ratio. Prolonged fasting (Option A) decreases insulin levels while increasing glucagon secretion to mobilize stored energy, resulting in a low I/G ratio. A low-carbohydrate diet (Option B) reduces insulin levels and increases glucagon secretion to maintain blood glucose levels, leading to a lower I/G ratio. During starvation (Option C) , the body relies heavily on glucagon to mobilize energy stores, resulting in a very low I/G ratio. Insulin Glucagon Ratio Condition Hepatic Glucose Storage/ Production I/G Ratio Features Large Carbohydrate Meal Storage 70 Indicates energy abundance Promotes glycogenesis, lipogenesis, and protein synthesis IV Glucose Storage 25 Small Meal Storage 7 Overnight Fasting Production 2.3 Indicates the need to mobilise energy stores Promotes glycogenolysis, gluconeogenesis, and ketogenesis Low Carbohydrate Diet Production 1.8 Starvation Production 0.4 Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 437 GK Pal Comprehensive Textbook of Medical Physiology, 1st Edition, Page 545

questions.question: Which of the following actions is NOT a physiological effect of glucagon?

options.A: Stimulating glycogen synthesis in the liver
options.C: Increasing glycogen breakdown in the liver

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Stimulating glycogen synthesis in the liver Explanation: Glucagon inhibits glycogen synthesis in the liver by inactivating glycogen synthase. It prevents the storage of glucose as glycogen, instead promoting glucose release into the bloodstream. Promoting gluconeogenesis (Option B): Glucagon activates enzymes involved in gluconeogenesis, increasing glucose production from non-carbohydrate sources, such as amino acids. Increasing glycogen breakdown in the liver (Option C): Glucagon stimulates glycogenolysis, breaking down glycogen stores in the liver to increase blood glucose levels. Enhancing lipolysis in the liver (Option D): Glucagon promotes lipolysis, breaking down triglycerides in the liver to free fatty acids and glycerol, which can be used for energy production. Glucagon Stimulators Inhibitors Amino acids (alanine, arginine) Cortisol Exercise Infections High blood glucose levels Somatostatin Insulin Free fatty acids and ketones Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 982.983 Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 436.437 GK Pal Comprehensive Textbook of Medical Physiology, 1st Edition, Page 544 Glucagon Physiology

questions.question: Which of the following does not stimulate insulin secretion? A. α -Adrenergic receptor activation β -Adrenergic receptors
questions.explanation: α -Adrenergic receptor activation Correct Answer: A) α -Adrenergic receptor activation Explanation: Activation of α -adrenergic receptors , typically by norepinephrine during sympathetic stimulation, inhibits insulin secretion. Parasympathetic activation enhances insulin secretion, through the release of acetylcholine, which acts on M3 receptors in pancreatic beta cells. (Option B) Stimulation of β 2-adrenergic receptors in the sympathetic system can promote insulin secretion, especially when the inhibitory effects of α -adrenergic receptors are blocked. (Option C) GLP-1 is an incretin hormone that stimulates insulin secretion in response to meals, aiding in the regulation of blood glucose levels. (Option D) INSULIN Stimulators of Insulin Release Inhibitors of Insulin Release Glucose Amino acids (e.g., arginine, lysine) Gastrointestinal hormones (e.g., GLP-1, GIP) Parasympathetic stimulation (via acetylcholine) β -Adrenergic receptor activation Sulfonylurea drugs Low Blood Glucose Somatostatin α -Adrenergic receptor activation Leptin Galanin Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 980,981 Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 433,434 GK Pal Comprehensive Textbook of Medical Physiology, 1st Edition, Page 531

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the mechanisms of action of oral hypoglycemic drugs is FALSE? release β -cells, stimulating insulin secretion even at low glucose concentrations.

options.A: GLP-1 analogues enhance insulin release only at high glucose concentrations and reduce glucagon
options.B: Sulfonylureas bind to the sulfonylurea receptor (SUR1) on pancreatic
options.C: GLP-1 analogues increase gastric emptying by stimulating specific GLP-1 receptors.
options.D: DPP-4 inhibitors increase endogenous GLP-1 levels by preventing its degradation.

questions.explanation: receptors. Correct Answer: C) GLP-1 analogues increase gastric emptying by stimulating specific GLP-1 receptors. Explanation: GLP-1 analogues slow gastric emptying and suppress appetite by activating specific GLP-1 receptors. ORAL HYPOGLYCEMIC DRUGS Sulphonylureas (Option B) Mechanism of action: Sulfonylureas bind to the sulfonylurea receptor (SUR1) on the membrane of pancreatic β -cells, which stimulates insulin secretion regardless of glucose concentration. This results in a significant and often unregulated release of insulin, potentially leading to severe hypoglycemia, especially at low glucose levels. Examples: Tolbutamide, Glipizide, Glibenclamide. GLP-1 Analogues (Option A) Mechanism of Action : GLP-1 analogues activate GLP-1 receptors, which are GPCRs located on pancreatic β -cells, α -cells, central and peripheral neurons, and gastrointestinal mucosa. This activation promotes insulin secretion specifically in response to high glucose levels, inhibits glucagon release, slows gastric emptying, and suppresses appetite. GLP-1 analogues also contribute to pancreatic β -cell health by reducing islet cell apoptosis. Examples : Exenatide, Liraglutide. DPP-4 Inhibitors (Option D) Mechanism of Action : DPP-4 inhibitors block the enzyme DPP-4, which normally breaks down endogenous GLP-1. By inhibiting this enzyme, these drugs increase the levels of GLP-1, thereby enhancing insulin secretion indirectly and improving glycemic control. Examples : Sitagliptin, Saxagliptin, Vildagliptin. Reference: KDT-Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th Edition, Page 292-294,297

questions.question: What is the primary mechanism by which glucose stimulates insulin secretion in pancreatic β -cells? β -cells, triggering immediate secretion. causing Ca2+ influx and insulin release. granules and affecting their release. β -cells without affecting ATP levels, thereby directly increasing the secretion of insulin.

options.A: Glucose stimulates insulin release directly by binding to its receptor on
options.B: Glucose is metabolized to pyruvate, increasing ATP, which inhibits ATP-sensitive K+ channels,
options.C: Glucose lowers intracellular glutamate, promoting insulin secretion by altering pH in secretory
options.D: Glucose enhances the uptake of calcium into the

questions.explanation: ATP-sensitive K+ channels, causing Ca2+ influx and insulin release. Correct Answer: B) Glucose is metabolized to pyruvate, increasing ATP, which inhibits ATP-sensitive K+ channels, causing Ca2+ influx and insulin release. Explanation: Glucose metabolism produces ATP, which inhibits ATP-sensitive K+ channels. This inhibition leads to depolarization of the β -cell membrane, causing Ca2+ influx through voltage-gated channels, and triggering insulin release. Insulin secretion is regulated through a biphasic response to plasma glucose levels. Biphasic response of Insulin secretion First Rapid Phase Second Prolonged Phase Glucose enters pancreatic β -cells via GLUT-2 transporters. Inside the cell, glucose is phosphorylated by glucokinase and converted to pyruvate. Pyruvate is metabolized in the mitochondria, producing ATP. (Option D) Increased ATP inhibits ATP-sensitive K+ channels, leading to reduced K+ efflux. This depolarizes the β -cell membrane, causing voltage-gated Ca2+ channels to open. Ca2+ influx triggers the exocytosis of a pool of insulin-containing granules, Results in a rapid, short-lived increase in insulin secretion. Peak within 1–2 minutes and then decreases to basal level in another 2 to 3 minutes Pyruvate metabolism increases intracellular glutamate levels. (Option C) Glutamate acts as an intracellular second messenger, priming a second pool of secretory granules for release. It may also lower the pH in granules, aiding in their maturation. This leads to a prolonged phase of insulin secretion . Peak in about 60 minutes and then remain elevated for 3–5 hours. Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 979,980 Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 433,434 GK Pal Comprehensive Textbook of Medical Physiology, 1st Edition, Page 531

questions.question: Match the following actions of insulin with the correct category: Categories: a) Increased by insulin b) Decreased by insulin Insulin Action: Cell growth Reabsorption of K+, Na+, and phosphate from the kidney Food intake Entry of phosphate and magnesium into the cell Body weight Lipolysis Potassium uptake into cells
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) a)-1,2,4,5,7 & b)-3,6 Explanation: a) Increased by insulin Cell growth : Insulin promotes cell growth and proliferation. Reabsorption of K+, Na+, and phosphate from the kidney : Insulin enhances the reabsorption of these electrolytes in the kidneys. Entry of phosphate and magnesium into the cell : Insulin facilitates the uptake of phosphate and magnesium into cells. Body weight : Insulin can increase body weight due to its effects on fat storage increasing adipose tissue mass. Potassium uptake into cells : Insulin promotes the movement of potassium into cells, which can lower blood potassium levels. Therefore is very useful in the management of acute renal failure. Insulin is considered a physiological regulator of plasma K+ concentration. b) Decreased by insulin Food intake : Insulin can promote satiety by increasing leptin levels in plasma, leading to decreased food intake. Also partly mediated by its inhibitory effect on neuropeptide Y release from the hypothalamus. Lipolysis : Insulin inhibits lipolysis, which is the breakdown of fats into fatty acids and glycerol. Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 426, 428 GK Pal Comprehensive Textbook of Medical Physiology, Page 538, 535-538 Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 975-979

questions.question: Which of the following are the actions of insulin? 1) Increased lipogenesis 2) Increased ketogenesis 3) Increased glycogen synthesis 4) Increased glucose uptake 5) Increased gluconeogenesis 6) Increased protein synthesis
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 1,3,4,6 Explanation: Lipogenesis: Insulin promotes the synthesis of fatty acids and triglycerides, especially in adipose tissue. Glycogen synthesis : Insulin stimulates glycogen synthesis in both muscle and liver tissues. Glucose uptake: Insulin increases glucose uptake into insulin-sensitive cells such as muscle and adipose tissue. Protein synthesis: Insulin promotes the uptake of amino acids into cells, enhancing protein synthesis. Ketogenesis: Insulin decreases ketogenesis. It reduces the breakdown of fatty acids and the formation of ketone bodies in the liver. (Option 2) Gluconeogenesis: Insulin inhibits gluconeogenesis in the liver, reducing the production of glucose (Option 5) Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 426, 428 GK Pal Comprehensive Textbook of Medical Physiology, 1st Edition, Page 538, 535-538 Guyton & Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 975-979

questions.question: A medical student curious about the physiological effects of insulin learns that insulin has rapid, intermediate, and delayed actions on various metabolic processes. Which of the following is an intermediate action of insulin?

options.A: Increased transport of K+ into insulin-sensitive cells
options.C: Increase in mRNAs for lipogenic enzymes
options.D: Increased transport of amino acids into insulin-sensitive cells

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Stimulation of protein synthesis Explanation: Stimulation of protein synthesis is an intermediate action of insulin that occurs within minutes. PRINCIPAL ACTIONS OF INSULIN Rapid (seconds) Increased transport of Glucose, Amino acids (Option D) K+ (Option A) into insulin-sensitive cells Intermediate (minutes) Stimulation of protein synthesis Inhibition of protein degradation Activation of glycolytic enzymes and glycogen synthase Inhibition of phosphorylase and gluconeogenic enzymes Delayed (hours) Increase in mRNAs for lipogenic and other enzymes (Option C) Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Pag. 975 Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 426

questions.question: Which of the following statements about insulin receptors, GLUT, and SGLT is correct? β subunits are responsible for insulin binding.

options.B: GLUT-4 transporters increase glucose uptake in response to insulin.
options.C: SGLT transporters primarily function in muscle and adipose tissue.
options.D: SGLT-2 inhibitors work by increasing glucose absorption in the kidneys.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) GLUT-4 transporters increase glucose uptake in response to insulin. Explantion: Insulin triggers the translocation of GLUT-4 transporters to the cell membrane, increasing glucose uptake. Insulin Receptor, GLUT, and SGLT Overview: Insulin Receptor : Structure: Tetramer of two α and two β glycoprotein subunits Synthesis: Single mRNA, separated via proteolysis, linked by disulfide bonds Gene Location: Chromosome 19, with 22 exons Subunit Functions : α Subunits : External, insulin-binding (Option A) β Subunits : Span the membrane, intracellular segments have tyrosine kinase activity Both subunits are glycosylated Mechanism: Insulin Binding : Triggers tyrosine kinase activity in β subunits Autophosphorylation : Of β subunits at tyrosine residues Signal Cascade : Phosphorylation/dephosphorylation of cytoplasmic proteins, mainly serine and threonine residues, mediated by insulin receptor substrate (IRS-1) and other effectors GLUT (Glucose Transporters) : Function: Facilitate glucose movement into cells Types: Seven known types have tissue-specific functions. GLUT-4: Primary Location : Muscle and adipose tissue (Option C) Regulation : Directly regulated by insulin Mechanism : Absence of Insulin : GLUT-4 in intracellular vesicles Presence of Insulin : Vesicles translocate and fuse with the cell membrane, increasing glucose uptake Exercise : Induces insulin-independent GLUT-4 translocation, aiding in blood glucose regulation SGLT (Sodium Glucose Linked Transporters): Function: Reabsorption of glucose in the kidneys (Option C) Mechanism: SGLT2 Location : Primarily in the proximal tubule of the nephron Co-transport Process : Utilises the sodium gradient created by the Na+/K+ ATPase pump to transport sodium and glucose from the renal tubular lumen into the cells Clinical Relevance: SGLT2 Inhibitors : Drugs like canagliflozin and empagliflozin Mechanism of Action : Prevent glucose reabsorption in the kidneys, leading to increased glucose excretion in urine (Option D) Therapeutic Use : Lower blood glucose levels in type 2 diabetes without causing hypoglycemia Note: Unlike other tissues, brain cells can take up and use glucose without the need for insulin. Reference: Guyton & Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 977 Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 426, 428 Sodium-Glucose Linked Transporters

questions.question: Which of the following statements about insulin synthesis is correct?

options.A: Insulin synthesis begins in the Golgi apparatus with the formation of proinsulin.
options.B: The C peptide is removed during the conversion of preproinsulin to proinsulin.
options.C: The insulin gene is located on the long arm of chromosome 11.
options.D: Insulin and C peptides are released from B cells in equimolar amounts.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Insulin and C peptides are released from B cells in equimolar amounts. Location : B cells of pancreatic islets Gene : Chromosome : Short arm of chromosome 11 (Option C) Structure : Three exons, two introns Key Steps in Insulin Synthesis: Preproinsulin to Proinsulin : Synthesis : Preproinsulin is synthesized in the rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER). (Option A) Folding : Preproinsulin folds and forms disulfide bonds to become proinsulin. C Peptide Role : C peptide links the A and B chains and is crucial for folding. Proinsulin to Insulin : Transport : Proinsulin moves to the Golgi apparatus. Packaging : It is packaged into membrane-bound granules. Proteolysis : Two proteases in the granules cleave the C peptide, producing insulin. (Option B) Storage : Insulin is stored within the granules. Secretion : Granule Movement : Granules move to the plasma membrane via microtubules. Exocytosis : Granules release insulin and C peptide into the bloodstream. Release Ratio : 90–97% of the released product is insulin, with an equimolar amount of C peptide (Option D) Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 425

questions.question: A 45-year-old female presents with a painless, enlarging neck mass. Ultrasound reveals multiple thyroid nodules. Which of the following histological findings is most consistent with an inactive thyroid gland?

options.A: Small follicles with cuboidal cells and minimal colloid
options.C: Numerous granular endoplasmic reticulum, lysosomes, and Golgi complexes

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Large follicles with abundant colloid Explanation: Large follicles with abundant colloids are characteristic of an inactive thyroid gland. Histology of Thyroid gland Formed by acini or thyroid follicles Thyroid Follicles: Shape: Spherical Consists of a single layer of epithelial cells surrounding a central colloid. Colloid is a viscous gel-like substance containing thyroglobulin. Inactive Gland: Follicles are large with abundant colloids. Active Gland: Follicles are small, cells are cuboidal, and colloid is present in small quantities. (Option A) Follicular cells Parafollicular cells The Apical Membrane of follicular cells faces the colloid and is covered with microvilli. The cytoplasm contains numerous granular endoplasmic reticulum, lysosomes, and Golgi complexes. Also known as C cells Located close to the follicles. Basal Membrane is in close contact with numerous capillaries in the interfollicular space. Secrete calcitonin. Numerous granular endoplasmic reticulum, lysosomes, and Golgi complexes (Option C) are present in follicular cells but do not differentiate between active and inactive states. Parafollicular cells secrete calcitonin (Option D) but are not indicative of the activity state of the thyroid gland.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the treatment of thyroid disorders is correct?

options.A: Propylthiouracil is used to treat hypothyroidism.
options.B: Radioactive iodine therapy is used for the treatment of Graves disease.
options.D: Hashimoto thyroiditis causes a long-term increase in thyroid hormone production.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Radioactive iodine therapy is used for the treatment of Graves disease. used in Graves disease. Hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism represent the two extremes of thyroid dysfunction, resulting from under-activity and overactivity of the thyroid gland, respectively. These conditions have distinct causes, symptoms, and treatments. Hypothyroidism: Causes: Iodine deficiency : Inadequate iodine intake inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis, leading to decreased secretion and compensatory thyroid hypertrophy eg. goiter. Autoimmune destruction : eg. Hashimoto thyroiditis (Option D) involves antibodies and immune cells attacking the thyroid gland, causing hypothyroidism. Pituitary or hypothalamic failure : Disruptions in the pituitary gland or hypothalamus → ↓ TSH or TRH → ↓ thyroid stimulation. Drug-induced hypothyroidism : eg. Amiodarone, Lithium Wolff-Chaikoff Effect: A mild and transient inhibition of iodide organic binding and hormone synthesis caused by large doses of iodide acting directly on the thyroid gland in healthy individuals. Clinical features: Reduced cognitive function, fatigue, lethargy. Cold intolerance Weight gain despite poor appetite Dry, yellowish skin (carotenemia) and puffiness (myxedema) due to protein complex accumulation. Constipation: Slowed digestive processes. Thinning hair on the scalp and/or other areas. Treatment: Addressing underlying causes: Iodine supplementation, hormone replacement therapy, and medication adjustments. Levothyroxine : Synthetic T4 administered to replace deficient thyroid hormone. (Option C) Hyperthyroidism: Causes: Graves disease : Autoimmune condition where antibodies stimulate the TSH receptor, leading to excessive T4 and T3 secretion and goiter. Toxic adenoma or multinodular goiter : Benign thyroid nodules autonomously produce thyroid hormones. Early stages of Hashimoto thyroiditis : Initial inflammation can cause a transient phase of hyperthyroidism. TSH-secreting pituitary tumor : Rare tumors secrete excessive TSH, overstimulating the thyroid gland. Symptoms: Nervousness and irritability: Increased CNS stimulation. Weight loss: Despite increased appetite (hyperphagia), elevated metabolism causes weight loss. Rapid heartbeat (tachycardia) and palpitations: Thyroid hormones stimulate cardiac function. Tremor: Fine tremor of the outstretched fingers. Eye changes: Protruding eyeballs (exophthalmos) in Graves disease. Treatment: Antithyroid medications : Thioureylenes like propylthiouracil (Option A) and methimazole inhibit thyroid hormone synthesis. Radioactive iodine therapy : Destroys thyroid tissue, reducing hormone production. Surgery : Removal of the thyroid gland, especially if the goiter is large and causing compressive symptoms.

questions.question: What is the primary metabolic consequence of fasting on thyroid hormone levels? A. ↑ T4 to T3 conversion, hence ↑ T3 B. ↓ T4 to T3 conversion, ↓ plasma T3 levels, and ↑ RT3 levels. C. ↓ T3 and normal RT3. D. ↑ BMR
questions.explanation: ↓ T4 to T3 conversion, ↓ plasma T3 levels, and ↑ RT3 levels. Correct Answer: B) ↓ T4 to T3 conversion, ↓ plasma T3 levels, and ↑ RT3 levels. Explanation: Prolonged fasting leads to decreased conversion of T4 to T3, leading to reduced plasma T3 levels and increased RT3 levels. Effect of diet on conversion of T4 to T3: Fasting: Decreases conversion of T4 to T3, reducing plasma T3 concentration. (Option A) Plasma T3 reduces by 10-20% within 24 hours and about 50% in 3-7 days. Facilitates conversion of T4 to RT3, increasing RT3 levels. Free and bound T4 levels remain normal. During prolonged starvation (severe,chronic fasting), RT3 returns to normal but T3 remains depressed. (Option C) Basal metabolic rate (BMR) falls. (Option D) Urinary nitrogen excretion, an index of protein breakdown, decreases. The decline in T3 conserves calories and protein Overfeeding: Increases T3. Decreased RT3.

questions.question: A 28 y/o woman visits her physician with complaints of weight loss, increased appetite, and anxiety. She feels warmer than usual and has noticed an increased frequency of bowel movements.O/E, her heart rate is elevated, and lab tests reveal elevated levels of thyroid hormones. Which of the following best describes the effects of thyroid hormones on metabolism in this patient?

options.A: Decrease oxygen consumption and promote energy storage in tissues.
options.B: Stimulate lipogenesis and reduce the turnover of glucose in the body.
options.C: Increase the rate of glucose absorption & lipid oxidation
options.D: Inhibit proteolysis, thereby conserving muscle mass and reducing metabolic activity.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Increase the rate of glucose absorption & lipid oxidation Explanation: Thyroid hormones promote glucose absorption, stimulate lipid oxidation, and hence increase overall energy expenditure. They increase BMR in every tissue except the anterior pituitary, brain, gonads, spleen, and lymph nodes. Functions of thyroid hormones: Effect of Thyroid hormone on metabolism Carbohydrate Metabolism Increase absorption of glucose from the intestine. Induce hepatic gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis, raising plasma glucose. Increase glucose turnover by enhancing its uptake and oxidation. (Option B) Fat Metabolism Stimulate lipolysis, releasing free fatty acids and glycerol. Increase lipid turnover and facilitate oxidation. Stimulate cholesterol synthesis, oxidation, and biliary excretion. Enhance hepatic uptake of cholesterol by increasing LDL receptor expression. Net effect: a significant decrease in plasma cholesterol and total lipid levels. Protein metabolism (Option D) Promote proteolysis in skeletal muscle, releasing amino acids. Increase protein turnover by enhancing protein degradation. Effects of Thyroid Hormone on CVS Heart Rate and Cardiac Output Increase the heart rate by upregulating and sensitizing β -receptors in the SA and AV nodes, leading to tachycardia in hyperthyroidism. Enhance myocardial contractility by increasing stroke volume hence increasing cardiac output (CO). Blood Pressure Systolic blood pressure : I heart rate and stroke volume results in increased CO Diastolic pressure: decreases due to calorigenic-induced thermogenic cutaneous vasodilation, resulting in decreased peripheral resistance. The overall effect is an increased pulse pressure, which is prominent in hyperthyroidism. Circulation Dynamics Enhanced cardiac output and vasodilation create hyperdynamic circulation, leading to shortened circulation time. Effects of Thyroid Hormone on other systems: Target system Functions CNS Important for the maturation of CNS especially during infancy and childhood Essential for overall brain functions including memory, learning, alertness, and reflexes. Lack of thyroid hormones during infancy can cause irreversible CNS development retardation. Skeletal muscle Thyroid hormones increase MHC gene expression in skeletal muscle, leading to muscle cramps and weakness in hypothyroidism. Hyperthyroidism also causes muscle weakness due to increased protein catabolism, with chronic cases resulting in thyrotoxic myopathy. Bones It is essential for normal growth, and musculoskeletal maturation, and promotes the expression of growth hormone (GH) genes. Increase

questions.question: A 35 y/o male presents with symptoms of lethargy, hair loss, and cold intolerance. His lab results show elevated T4 levels but low T3 levels. Which of the following best explains the relationship between T4 and T3 in this patient? synchronous production. hormone.

options.A: T4 is the primary thyroid hormone and is converted to the more active T3 in peripheral tissues.
options.B: T3 has a longer half-life than T4, allowing it to maintain steady levels in the bloodstream.
options.C: Elevated T4 levels automatically indicate that T3 levels should also be elevated, due to their
options.D: T4 is biologically active, while T3 is inactive and serves primarily as a storage form of thyroid

questions.explanation: peripheral tissues. Correct Answer: A) T4 is the primary thyroid hormone and is converted to the more active T3 in peripheral tissues. Explanation: T4 is the primary thyroid hormone secreted by the thyroid gland, and it is converted to the more active T3 in peripheral tissues. Difference between T4 & T3 Aspect T4 T3 Secretion More (35% of total) Less (7% of total) Plasma conc. 8 mg/dL 0.15 mg/dL Protein-bound 99.8% 99.8% Free concentration in plasma 2 ng/dL 0.3 ng/dL Half-life (t1/2) (Option B) 7 days 1 day Action Slower Faster Potency Less More (3-5 times) Binding to thyroid hormone receptors Low affinity High affinity T4 and T3 (Option C) can be produced independently, and high T4 does not guarantee high T3 levels and depends on its peripheral conversion. T3 is the biologically active form of thyroid hormone, not T4 (Option D) Reference: GK Pal Comprehensive Textbook of Medical Physiology, 1st Edition, Page 485,485,488

questions.question: A 50 y/o male presents with fatigue, weight gain, and feeling cold. Blood tests show normal T4, low T3, and elevated RT3 levels. Which of the following best explains the patient's symptoms and lab findings?

options.A: Increased activity of 5´-deiodinase in the liver and kidney
options.D: Reduced secretion of thyroxine (T4) from the thyroid gland

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Increased activity of 5-deiodinase Explanation: Increased activity of 5-deiodinase leads to increased conversion of T4 to RT3 by 5-deiodinase leading to higher levels of the physiologically inert RT3 and lower levels of the active T3 Peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 The peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 is a crucial process that regulates the active thyroid hormone T3 levels, ensuring its availability to target cells. The major product secreted by the thyroid gland is thyroxine (T4) Conversion to T3 35% of secreted T4 is converted to T3 in the circulation by the enzyme 5'-deiodinase, mainly found in the liver and kidneys. This process produces about 85% of circulating T3, the most active hormone that primarily affects target cells. Conversion to RT3 45% of T4 is also converted to reverse T3 (RT3) by the enzyme 5-deiodinase. RT3 is physiologically inert and accounts for 95% of circulating RT3. The remaining 20% of T4 is conjugated with sulfates and glucuronides. Deiodinase Deiodinases are enzymes responsible for the metabolism of thyroid hormones. They play a crucial role in regulating the levels of active thyroid hormones in various tissues. All deiodinases contain selenocysteine, an amino acid essential for their enzyme activity, making them potent catalysts for oxidoreductive reactions. There are three types of deiodinases: Type of deiodinase Location Function D1 Liver Kidney Thyroid Pituitary Function as 5´-deiodinases, converting thyroxine (T4) to triiodothyronine (T3) Maintaining intracellular T3 levels in target tissues D2 Skeletal muscle Brain Pituitary Placenta Brown fat Its function is the same as D1 It maintains a steady supply of T3 to neurons in the brain. D3 Brain Reproductive tissue Converts T4 to reverse T3 (RT3), a biologically inactive form. Metabolism of T3 and T4: T3 is degraded to diiodothyronines in the liver and kidney. In the liver, T4 and T3 undergo conjugation with sulfates and glucuronic acid, which are then secreted in bile and re-enter the enterohepatic circulation, minimizing iodine loss. T4 is also metabolized to tetraiodoacetic acid (tetrac) in various tissues. Increased activity of 5´-deiodinase (Option A) would lead to higher levels of T3, not lower, which contradicts the patient's lab findings. Decreased activity of 5-deiodinase (Option B) would result in reduced levels of RT3, not elevated levels as seen in the patient. The patient has normal T4 levels, indicating that thyroxine secretion is not the issue. (Option D) Reference: GK Pal Comprehensive Textbook of Medical Physiology, 1st Edition, Page 486-487

questions.question: A 30y/o pregnant woman has elevated thyroid-binding globulin (TBG) but shows no symptoms of thyroid dysfunction. Her endocrinologist explains this is common during pregnancy and that her thyroid function remains normal. Which of the following best explains why the pregnant woman is experiencing this? clearance rate of thyroid hormones

options.A: TSH secretion is decreased due to elevated TBG levels
options.B: Elevated TBG levels reduce the production of thyroid hormones
options.C: A temporary fall in free thyroid hormones stimulates TSH secretion, restoring equilibrium
options.D: Increased TBG levels compensate for the reduced free hormone levels by decreasing the metabolic

questions.explanation: equilibrium Correct Answer: C) A temporary fall in free thyroid hormones stimulates TSH secretion, restoring equilibrium Explanation: TBG levels are increased in pregnancy which binds to the thyroid hormone and reduces the levels of free thyroid hormone in the blood, this temporary fall in thyroid hormone stimulates TSH secretion, thereby restoring equilibrium. Consequences of Increased TBG Due to Pregnancy TBG Elevation During Pregnancy : TBG levels are elevated in estrogen-treated patients and during pregnancy, necessitating the above compensatory mechanisms to maintain thyroid hormone balance. Initial Impact : Decrease in Free Thyroid Hormones : A sudden, sustained increase in thyroid-binding proteins like TBG in the plasma causes a temporary fall in the concentration of free thyroid hormones Increased TBG levels do bind more thyroid hormones, reducing the levels of free hormones temporarily. Overall binding capacity increases, but it does not necessarily compensate by decreasing the metabolic clearance rate significantly. The primary compensatory mechanism is the increased TSH secretion, which restores free hormone levels. (Option D) Feedback Mechanism : TSH Secretion: The drop in free thyroid hormones stimulates the secretion of Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH). (Option A) Increased Production: TSH increases the production of free thyroid hormones. New Equilibrium: A new equilibrium is reached where the total quantity of thyroid hormones in the blood is elevated (Option B) , but the concentration of free hormones, their metabolism rate, and the TSH secretion rate return to normal. Euthyroid State: Despite the increased total thyroid hormone levels, patients remain euthyroid, meaning they are neither hyperthyroid nor hypothyroid. Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 360

questions.question: A 38y/o woman presents with symptoms of fatigue, weight gain, and dry skin. Laboratory tests reveal low free T4 and elevated TSH levels. Further investigation shows increased levels of thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG). Which of the following is most likely to be associated with increased levels of thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG)
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Estrogen Explanation: Estrogen is seen to cause an increase in levels of thyroxine-binding globulin Thyroid Binding Proteins Thyroid hormones bind with 3 types of plasma proteins Thyroxine Binding Globulin (TBG) Nature: Glycoprotein synthesized by the liver with a molecular weight of 54,000. Binding Capacity: Each TBG molecule has a single binding site for thyroid hormones. Binding Proportion : About 70% of T4 and 45% of T3 bind to TBG. Plasma Level Influences: Increase: During pregnancy and in patients receiving estrogen, major tranquilizers, and clofibrate. Decrease: In patients receiving glucocorticoids, androgens, danazol, L-asparaginase, salicylates, phenytoin, mitotane, and 5-fluorouracil (Option A, B, C) Thyroxine Binding Prealbumin (TBPA) /Transthyretin Nature: A globulin, not an albumin, recently designated as transthyretin. Binding Proportion: T3: Less than 1% binds to TBPA. T4: About 20% binds to TBPA. Albumin Binding Proportion: T3: About 55% binds to albumin. T4: About 10% binds to albumin. Importance of Protein Binding Reservoir Function: Protein-bound forms of T3 and T4 serve as a reservoir, replenishing circulating hormones when secretion decreases or metabolism increases temporarily. Protection Against Degradation: Protein binding protects the hormones against metabolic degradation, extending their half-lives (1 day for T3 and 7 days for T4). Regulation of Hormone Secretion: Free-form concentrations provide feedback effects on hormone regulation. Changes in plasma protein levels temporarily affect thyroid hormone levels, maintaining a euthyroid state despite alterations in binding protein levels. Reference: GK Pal Comprehensive Textbook of Medical Physiology, 1st Edition, Page 486 Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 360

questions.question: A patient with a history of Graves' disease is treated with a high dose of iodide. Initially, there is a reduction in thyroid hormone synthesis due to the Wolff-Chaikoff effect. However, after a few days, the patient's thyroid function returns to normal. Which of the following mechanisms explains this "escape" phenomenon?

options.D: Increased conversion of T4 to T3 in peripheral tissues

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Downregulation of the sodium-iodide symporter (NIS) Explanation: Downregulation of the sodium-iodide symporter (NIS) reduces the intrathyroidal concentration of iodide, allowing normal thyroid hormone synthesis to resume despite high serum iodide levels. Wolff-Chaikoff Effect The Wolff-Chaikoff effect describes the thyroid's response to high doses of iodide, resulting in temporary inhibition of thyroid hormone synthesis. Mechanism: Inhibition of Organic Binding: Large doses of iodide inhibit the organic binding of iodide within the thyroid gland, reducing hormone synthesis. TSH Effect Inhibition: High iodide levels decrease cAMP production in thyroid cells, inhibiting the effect of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). (Wolff-Chaikoff effect) This reduces the proteolysis of thyroglobulin, further decreasing hormone synthesis. Purpose The Wolff-Chaikoff effect serves to prevent the thyroid from synthesizing excessive amounts of thyroid hormones in the presence of large quantities of iodide. Thyroid Escape Phenomenon: The Wolff-Chaikoff effect is transient and lasts for only a few days. After the acute phase, the thyroid gland resumes normal hormone synthesis through the escape phenomenon. This is achieved by: Down-regulation of NIS: The sodium iodide symporter (NIS) is down-regulated, reducing intrathyroidal inorganic iodine concentration. Resumption of TPO-H2O2 System: Normal activity of the thyroid peroxidase (TPO) and hydrogen peroxide system resumes, allowing the normal synthesis of thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3). Increased degradation of thyroglobulin (Option A) does not explain the escape phenomenon Upregulation of the sodium-iodide symporter (NIS) (Option B) would increase iodide uptake, which is contrary to the escape mechanism. Increased conversion of T4 to T3 (Option C) in peripheral tissues is unrelated to the escape phenomenon in the context of thyroid hormone synthesis regulation. Reference: GK Pal Comprehensive Textbook of Medical Physiology, 1st Edition, Page 486,493 Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 365 Iodine-induced hypothyroidism

questions.question: A patient presents with symptoms of hypothyroidism despite adequate iodine intake. Upon investigation, it is found that there is a defect in the enzyme responsible for a key step in thyroid hormone synthesis. Which of the following steps in thyroid hormone synthesis is not facilitated by thyroid peroxidase (TPO)?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Iodide trapping Explanation: Iodide trapping involves the active transport of iodide into the thyroid follicular cells via the sodium-iodide symporter (NIS) and is not facilitated by thyroid peroxidase. Thyroid Hormone Synthesis 1. Iodide Trapping Mechanism: Iodide is actively transported into thyroid follicles (iodide pump). Process: Na+ and I I co-transported into the cell by Na+-I I symporter (NIS).TSH induces expression and retention of NIS. Na+ is pumped out by the Na+-K+ pump. Iodide is pumped against electrical and chemical gradients using ATP. Other Tissues: Salivary glands, placenta, choroid plexus, mammary gland, gastric mucosa, and ciliary body also accumulate iodide but do not form thyroid hormones. Iodide trapping is stimulated by TSH. 2. Conversion of Iodide into Iodine Process: Iodide is converted to iodine by oxidation. Oxidation (organification) facilitated by thyroid peroxidase. (Option A) 3. Thyroglobulin Synthesis Thyroglobulin: Glycoprotein with two subunits and 123 tyrosine residues. Synthesis: Synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum of thyroid cells. Packaged in Golgi apparatus and secreted into colloid by exocytosis. Facilitated by thyroid peroxidase. (Option D) Binding: Reactive iodine binds to tyrosine on thyroglobulin, forming monoiodotyrosine (MIT) and diiodotyrosine (DIT). 4. The Coupling Reaction Formation: Two DIT molecules condense to form thyroxine (T4). MIT and DIT condense to form triiodothyronine (T3). Reverse-T3 (RT3) formed by condensation of DIT with MIT. Mechanism: Intramolecular coupling (both DIT attached to thyroglobulin). Intermolecular coupling (DIT detached from thyroglobulin). Facilitation: Coupling reaction facilitated by thyroid peroxidase ( Option B) . 5. Proteolysis of Thyroglobulin Process: Colloid ingested by thyroid cells via endocytosis. Lysosomal enzymes digest peptide bonds in thyroglobulin. Free T4, T3, DIT, and MIT formed in the cytoplasm. Iodotyrosine deiodinase deiodinates MIT and DIT. T3 and T4 are released into circulation. Iodine from deiodination is reutilized by the gland. 6. Secretion of Thyroid Hormones Release: T3 and T4 are secreted into general circulation. MIT and DIT are not secreted by the thyroid gland. Functions of Thyroid Cells: Accumulate iodide from blood. Synthesize and secrete thyroglobulin. Digest colloid and release thyroid hormones.
